item.title: Reproducible journal articles
item.description: A few months ago, I wrote a post about my experiences of writing up a PhD thesis reproducible using $\LaTeX$ and R via knitr. Since then I have started to write up much of my PhD work into academic papers for peer review, so in this post I’m documenting a number of new lessons I have learnt over the last five months. I’m working on four papers at present, one of which is under review, and I hope to make the source code available as these appear in print.

item.title: Too hot to cycle?
item.description: Last year I played around a bit with the New York Citibike data, and looked a little bit at the different use patterns among among the sexes, and between subscribers and ad hoc users of the service. Being an Englishman, I was also wondering if there were differences between the patterns of bike usage on different sides of the Atlantic, so I recently got hold of the 20 million odd records of Barclay Bike data from the Transport for London open data portal.

item.title: Writing a PhD thesis in LaTeX and R
item.description: About a year into the PhD thesis writing process, I decided to make a switch from a widely known WhatYouSeeisWhatYouGet word processor, into $\LaTeX$. It all started with a black line at the bottom of the page. It appeared one day while I was writing a riveting chapter on soil carbon, and looked like a border on top of the footer. I don’t know where it came from, and no matter what I tried, I couldn’t get rid of it.
